bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emilie M.] Reed, September 1941

div1.p: Hench asks Reed for permission to show some of her father's letters to Wood.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emilie M.] Reed, September 1941
div1.opener:
Copy
not to be sent until I get Gen. Reed's permission
to send it.
September 1941
My dear Miss Reed:
div1.p:
I am indeed glad to hear from various sources that you are improving
notably and that it is probable that you will be up and around quite soon.

I hate very much indeed to bother you at all while you are in the hospital
but a matter has come up about which a decision must be made and as it concerns
your distinguished father, I am taking the liberty of dropping you this note.
As you may know, a Miss Laura Wood of Washington, D. C. has been asked to write
a book for children, about your father. She has been trying to uncover various
sources of information, particularly old letters of your father's. Some months
ago when she first wrote me, I also had a letter from your brother and from
General Kean saying that so far as they knew she seemed to be a responsible per-
son and I was encouraged to help her as much as I could. I have therefore given
her a fairly large amount of material, part of it from Dr. Kelly's collection
which he has given me, and part of it from material which I have collected myself.

You will remember that after the Cleveland unveiling you were kind enough
to let me read the intensely interesting manuscript which you had written about
your father and in which you had included many of his letters. I mentioned to
you that these letters were invaluable to me as they gave certain dates and remarks
about which there had been some doubt and you were kind enough to give me permission
to copy such portions as would be useful to me. I only did so with the explicit
understand that I would not use these letters in any way that would interfere with
the publication value of your own manuscript. Although the first part of your
manuscript was most interesting, I only made copies of your father's letters as
of 1900-1901, that is, the very last part of your manuscript. As I said, I can
assure you that these will not be used by me except as background information and
to authenticate dates and your father's movements.

Miss Wood has heard of this manuscript and I believe has been trying to
get to see you and to borrow it from you or a member of your family. Naturally,
because of your illness, this has been impossible. The point I wish to ask you
about is this: would you be willing to have me lend her my copy of your father's
letters as of 1900-1901 with the understanding that I will insist that she use them
as I had intended to use them--only for background information and to corroborate
dates of your father's whereabouts. I have never met Miss Wood and of course can
not touch for her personally although her letters breathe an atmosphere of entire
reliability. Her book is to be published by the Julian Messner Co., New York City.
I would not bother you were it not for the fact that her date line is Nov. 1 and
already she is getting rather distraught, nor would I bother you except for the
Miss Reed
- 2 -
September 1941
additional fact that she seems sincerely to want to honor your father as
I, myself, want to.
With every sincere wish for your early complete recovery, I remain,
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
